options: Alert you registrar to the problem
Ask the ward pharmacist to correct the charts for you
Let things continue as they are
After the ward round speak to your consultant for advice on the situation
Rewrite every prescription yourself after each WR but don't say anything
questions:
You consistently find that your registrar writes prescriptions that are barely legible and the nurses often bleep you with problems giving the prescribed medication. How should you address the situation?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question is about communication and patient safety.

EXPLANATION
  • 1 - Alert the reg. This addresses the problem directly
  • 4 - Speak to your consultant. Since this action is going to happen immediately and it has the option of solving an underlying problem it is a good option but not as good as speaking to the reg directly
  • 5 - Rewrite. This protects patient safety but does not address the problem
  • 2 - Ask the pharmacist. This would also protect patient safety but is escalating outside your team
  • 3 - Let things continue. Although this is a patient safety issue it doesn't make things worse.

KEY POINTS
  • Patient safety
  • Escalate inside your team before going outside

REFERENCES

Good Medical Practice - http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/goodmedicalpractice/recordwork.asp

options: Explain to him your concerns and ask him if he has been drinking alcohol
Contact your medical indemnity provider for advice
Discuss your concerns with the other partners in the surgery
Use the CAGE screening tool to assess whether he is an alcoholic
questions:
Whilst speaking to one of the senior partners at your GP surgery you notice the smell of alcohol on his breath.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The most appropriate response is to directly challenge your colleague about your concerns. As a doctor you have a duty of care to protect patients - a doctor under the influence of alcohol is a potential danger to patients. The next best option is to discuss your concerns with one of the other partners. This would hopefully result in the same action being taken but following a delay.

Phoning your medical indemnity provider is not really necessary as the correct course of action is clear. They would however hopefully advise you on the correct course of action. By using the CAGE screening tool you are starting to act as your colleagues doctor which is not appropriate. If they have a problem with alcohol they need to see their own GP. Although drinking alcohol whilst practising medicine is dangerous and unprofessional is it not a direct matter for the police.

The GMC state the following:
'You should follow the advice in Good Medical Practice in relation to your own health. You should also:
- protect those you manage from risks to their health
- protect patients from risks arising from your own or your colleagues' health
- respond constructively to signs that colleagues have health problems; in particular you
- should be alive to mental health problems, depression, and alcohol and drug dependence
- help and support colleagues who have health problems.'
